name: SightSPEED

screenshots.caption: The level menu showing the author's best times about a month after writing the program.  Your daily total is in seconds and can be used to set a daily practise goal.
Levels 1 to 6 display one note per hand at a time, starting in straight scales and increasing in movement.
Levels 7 to 12 introduce two notes per hand.
Levels 13-18 display two notes per hand at once.  If you can beat these levels, you are probably a robot.

short_description:
SightSPEED is a "gamified" teaching utility for sight-reading music.  A 73- or 88-note, MIDI-equipped piano is required to play.  There are 18 levels for each of the 12 keys.

SightSPEED teaches note recognition.  Other components of sight reading (rhythm, meter, dynamics) are not covered, but it is assumed that players will pick these elements up naturally from playing real music.

SightSPEED is designed around four-part vocal pieces (a.k.a. SATB scores), which are said to be the best material for sight-reading practice.  Hymnals contain tons of songs in four-part harmony.

After seven years of playing piano by ear, I grew tired of being limited by my hearing skills and decided to learn to read music.  I tried learning by reading real songs, but I found it annoying, so I started experimenting with randomly-generated exercizes because I found them less frustrating.  SightSPEED is the fifth or sixth program I've written for this purpose.
summary: A program to help people learn to sight-read using a digital piano.
